title: Cathodic protection for extending the life of concrete bridges

author: Rob Polder, Delft University of Technology (TU Delft)

segmentation: The last speaker will be Rob older senior scientist at TNO built environment and Geoscience and is part time professor at Technical University Delft in civil engineering working on durability at concrete conclusion in particular so it will talk about cathodic protection for extending the life of concrete bridges.
Please proceed to Mr Chairman.
Before I start talking about data protection, I was just linking to under his leg ATS.
Mentioning, of course 534.
I was a chairman of that action and I'm still the final editor of that final report of that.
And it's gonna be printed and sent to at least the participants in cost 54 and I think two months time.
So if you're interested in that work about new materials and systems and methods for prestressed concrete structures and their durability, just let me know.
I will probably be able to send you one of those 500 page books.

In short, time OK. Having said that, I'm going to speak about cathodic protection for extending the life of concrete bridge is reporting on some of the work that we did in artist together with Zach and and your letter doors concrete repair company an other people around in the group.
Let me see.
Previous speakers about corrosion and durability have have explained how the mechanism works and what faces are in the life of a concrete structure now.
This is about passing the initiation.
Arriving somewhere in the middle of undresses.
Diagram where you will have actual corrosion, sports and cracks and some of the steel is crowding, and this may be due to deicing salts or seawater that.
Penetrate chlorides and will it will affect your service ability of your structure and at some point in time who knows when the safety of the structure as well.
Now if you have a case like this where there is obvious corrosion spots and some of the concrete has pulled off and some of the bars have been exposed.
What can you do?
What are the options?
Well, in my simple schematic here we have four options.
First, you can do nothing and then later you have to explain why you did nothing when it went wrong I think.
2nd is conventional repair.
And there's two varieties of conventional repair.

In some cases they do quick and dirty repair, which is taking off the delaminated concrete, clean it a little bit, and then put some new mortar in it, which I call quick and dirty because it has short life and it will be cracking and corrupting again in a couple of years.
Full thorough repair means generally that you will have to take out all the chloride contaminated concrete in many cases behind the rebars.
In some cases, even down to the prestressing steel, which can be rather tricky.
But that is the way to go to get a serious and full thorough repair.
Third option is cathartic protection, which is the main.
Issue of my presentation.
CP in short, that always involves a little bit of repair, but not as the main mechanism of corrosion protection.
And finally, you can also replace the structure or the structural element.
Those.
Study options.
Now, some of the horrible examples that may necessitate taking drastic protection measurements measures.
This is the picture that I showed before.
It is part of that.

Bridge and the motorway system around Zagreb where our colleagues from Croatia took us this winter and showed us some of their leaking and cracking and corro Ding structures which are at this moment structurally completely safe but may need some attention into new.
Future.
Some smaller examples from Slovenia collected by our colleagues from Zach.
Simple, relatively simple bridge substructures that suffer from penetration of deicing salt water leaking through leaking joints.
Somewhere in the bridge deck system coming down to the substructures chlorate penetrates relatively fast.
And corrosion starts.
But relatively locally so.
You do not have to repair the complete structure or replace the complete structure if you'd like to replace it.
You can concentrate on the really suffering parts or end, or the.
Structurally important parts.
Now let's turn to cathodic protection.
Just in a nutshell because it is late and we'd like to have a drink or smoke, or at least a breath of fresh air after this long session.
Public protection stops corrosion.
It interferes with the electrochemical process of corrosion and it simply stops it as long as there is enough current and current is permanent, etc etc.
But that's what you have to know about the principle.
It needs a low voltage direct current power system and material on the concrete service, which we call NOAA.
And some circuitry.

So you have to have some some copper cables and the concrete should be continuous and conducting, and the steel should be continuous and conducting, but those are the little technical details that you can leave to the experts.
Now every cathodic protection system by the European standard is tested twice or even four times a year.
With an electrical test that proves the absence of corrosion.
If the test is not positive, then the system is adjusted in order to make it work positive by the next test.
So if Gothic protection system works and is properly maintained, then you get at least twice a year and let us saying your structure is not corrupting.
An interesting question could be how long will such a system last?
Well, we have recently updated our survey of cathodic protection systems in the Netherlands, which at this point is about 125 systems.
By the way, Denmark and Norway have 200 each.
the United Kingdom has about 500 systems, so there's experience from.
1000 or even a couple of 1000 systems worldwide.
My little results and figures are about the Dutch situation, but I'm pretty sure that.
This is as a wider application.
We have found that the probability that the CP system works is 90%.
Up to an age of 13 years, that means that up to 13 years, only 10% of those CP systems fails.

That means that the average working life of a CP system is much more than 13 years, and these relate mainly to pretty light, relatively easy and cheap cathodic protection system based on conductive coatings.
Assistance with activated titanium.
This is another technicality, of course, but you might.
Remember the word titanium have working lives of at least 25 years and probably much, much more.
OK click protection in particular because of its longer working life will cost less over the total life of a bridge.
Remaining life of a bridge and it will cause lower out of service times before repairs than conventional repair.
There's.
Let me go into detail about the design of product protection just a little bit, by the way, cathartic protection does not bring back steel that has corroded away.

So if you have a structural problem 'cause that protection is not going to help you, you have to be sure before designing and applying a CP system, you have to be sure that the structural capacity is OK. We're not touching that.
We only stop ongoing corrosion.
OK, once you have decided that the structural safety is fine, you can locate the corrosion.
And the damage by, for instance, potential mapping.
And there's talked about that.

You should check the steel continuity because you want all the reinforcing steel to be part of the electrical circuit and you should also check the electrical conductance and continuity of the concrete.
Then you have to choose the N out material and its location.
In what part of the surface or cross section will you put the NOAA?
An if you want to go for a very critical, that is a very slender, cheap, smart, whatever kind of CP system you may want to model the performance of a system in the design stage.
I will come back to that just a little bit later.
Now down here we have a very brief overview of the types of inodes.
One is a conductive coating which can be put on top on the bottom on the side or the side of a column.
It's like a paint, it has a black layer that is the active layer and a normal concrete paint.
Goes on top so you don't.
You won't see the difference.
The other type that is used most widely is titanium mesh.
Which is a sort of a sturdy chicken wire that's black, of course.
That can be modelled around columns or underneath surface or top of a bridge deck that always has to have some cementitious overlay, like shotcrete or a cast concrete layer.
An variation is that you can use titanium strips inside a cross section or in slots in the in the surface.
Without going.
Into details just a few pictures here.
See a very nice and rare by the way, example of all stages of application of titanium mesh and shotcrete on the extreme left you see the original surface which is dirty.
This is marine environment.
And then a small strip of cleaned and group lasted well prepared concrete surface.
Then a titanium mesh that is fixed with plastic pins, plastic fixings and just in the next.
Strip you see the shotcrete applied well.
Over the titanium mesh, like two or three centimeters stick.
Another type, as I said is a CP system based on titanium strips and this is what was done in the trial site.
Within Arch is the work of arch is in Poland on the top left you see a leaking drainage that has deposited chlorides and water.
In this area you see some spalling.
He ran considerable cracking and spalling here of probably structurally important reinforcement.
When they, when they broke out the the loose parts, by the way, only the loose parts.
Not not any heavy breaking out.
You see that there was a lot of spalling and delamination and corroded reinforcement next phases.
This was repaired superficially and then titanium strips were placed on top.
I think Thomas also showed the detailed pictures and finally it's a little piece of mortar dike put around the titanium strip.
The system has been energized as far as I can tell, but only recently, so we do not have.
Measuring results of that.
The second case I would like to talk about a little bit more.
Is there kinetic protection trial here in Slovenia, which is the place that the excursion tomorrow will take us?
I think as the first.
Stop on the excursion.
Yes, thank you.
I really recommend going there.
It's a lovely place under a bridge.
Here you can see that.
Yeah, well, it's mainly cross beams below a pretty large big bridge deck that showed some cracking and spalling and rust staining.
And here they took off the.
The loose parts exposing the reinforcement initial seeds as well corroded.
There's some chloride here, but also combination so you have a little bit more of a general corrosion aspect than the usual pitting corrosion.
All the damage was repaired by the way, quick and dirty, so just the loose material and then repair it, which is OK for concrete.
It's not OK for only conventional repair.
It's OK for.
Cathartic protection and then three different N out systems were applied as part of the study that we were doing in in this work on the left you see titanium strips on a horizontal row all along.
The cantilever heads placed in little mortar dikes.
You're going to see more of that tomorrow if you go on the excursion test area, two had conductive coating on the sites, not on the top and bottom layer.
In this area, three had only titanium strips on the head and not in the body of the beam.
Now you might say is that a good idea?
No, it was not a good idea.
We knew before hand that the protection from these handouts would not reach the ultimate.
The most distant steal at that point, but we wanted to do the experiment, do the modeling, and do the testing just to make sure that our modeling was also able to assess the most critical aspects.
OK, so we're going to test different materials configurations, and we're going to check that.
With finite element modeling, which I give a picture here.
This is the result of a finite element modeling of cathodic protection or sealing concrete.
Which needs you to make a real geometrical model of the concrete element that you're going to study.
You have to locate the steel at the right positions and in the right amount and the right depth.
So you need to know the cover depth of the thing you're gonna model.

And you need some more input parameters that is related to the corrosion and electrochemical aspects of stealing concrete, which I'm not going into right now that took us quite awhile to get that right.
And still some work needs to be done on that.
Next issue is that at the moment we're only able to make 2D models if we really need to make 3D models, then the computation time is still too long to really get it done well.
But in most cases you can make a smart cross section in 2D through any structure.

So the input the, let's say the the the load you put on it is the external voltage and the concrete resistivity, and then the output is the current and the potential and the potential distribution at the current distribution as a function of place in your little cross section.
Now what we see here is the model for test Area 3 where we had five titanium strips on the head.
And nothing here in a 5 metre long beam.
And the the plot.
The color plot informs you about the polarization.
That means that.
The amount that the steel is polarized out of its ordinary its.
Previous situation and you might simply state that as long as your polarization is like 100 or a little bit more millivolts, then the protection of that steel is OK.
If it is really less than 100 millivolts, it is not OK so.
It's pretty hard to see, but this is the critical color boundary between good and bad, and roughly you'll find it here.
So all the steel in this part is well protected.
Which could be expected from the beginning and the steel from here on is increasingly not being protected.
Actually, there's no current arriving here, so there's no polarization.
Now, is this exactly what we measured?
In practice?
It is not exactly what we measured in practice.
Actually, we had only electrodes in this part, not here, which was not too smart.
But all those electrodes here indicated that there was no serious polarization, so.
Roughly, the agreement between experiment and modeling is is good, and we feel pretty confident at the moment that we can.
We can predict the behavior of cathartic protection systems.
Case with good confidence and for difficult cases, I think it could be a useful tool.
Not talking about lifecycle cost.

We had some information on the cost of the trial in Slovenia, which by the way was about 150 square meters of concrete surface, and the input for the calculations was that full repair cost, 540 euros per square meter.
Cosmetic protection cost 405 euros per square meter plus a fixed amount for.
Any project like 16,000 plus another 1000 euros a year for the control measurements?
So the price of CP grows over the years.
So maybe at some point in the far future it could be the same.
The total cost life cycle cost could be the same As for conventional repairing.
Well it is, but not until 13 years.
And then CP is 7000 euros cheaper for this case than conventional repair.
However, what after 13 years?
You might think that both cathodic protection and a repaired structure need new maintenance after 13 years.
Yes, that may be true however.
On the basis of our inventory, we feel that the probability of failure of cathodic protection at year 13 is only 10%.
Now the probability of failure of conventional repair in year 13 is probably more than 50% of European inventory.
In rehab, condo, hip, net, couple of years ago showed that conventional repairs at a working life with a 50% of probability of failure like 10 years or even less.
So let me draw some conclusions.
Cathodic protection is a proven technique.
There's plenty of examples that show that corrosion is completely stopped by cathodic protection.
In that sense, it is more effective than conventional repair, where some corrosion may be going on.
Some corrosion may be reappearing petition.
Turning it the other way round, if you repair a structure then use cathodic protection to prolong the life of the repairs.
Could be an approach.
In any case, the lifetime of protection system is well over 10 years and four titanium systems well over 25 years, so you will have a long life of your protection system.
Flexible design is possible, and different materials and components are available on the market, so you can.
You can tailor make your CP system for your structure.
And we have found that modeling in the design stage may be beneficial.
Increase in critical cases, for instance, where you want a really cheap and slim and slender.
CP system.
Coming back to the advantages of CP.
You have less demolition.
You do not have to take out a lot of concrete behind the rebars, which means that also you might have a shorter out of traffic time and you produce less waste material.
That as a corrosion protection solution is it is reliable and safe.
And it has lower maintenance costs.
It will be cheaper than replacement in many many many cases.
There is an example in the.
In the deliverable.
And it will be more durable than conventional repair in many many cases.
So if you want more details then I refer to the arches deliverable guideline D12.
I think it is.
Having said that, thank you for your attention.
